channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Grow Your Karma with a Job that Does Good! Perl role in Australia
item.description: Not all jobs are created equal. Sure, most pay the bills, but some do more. They impart a sense of purpose; when you log out at day’s end, it’s with the satisfaction that you are part of something bigger, something more important than yourself. You’ve left the world a little better than you found it, and isn’t that what life is really about?

item.title: Guten Tag, Senior Perl Developers! Perl role in South Germany
item.description: With more than 4 million domains spanning nearly every country around the globe, our client manages over 100,000 retail and corporate clients and 2,300 resellers.The ideal candidate should be confident using Modern Perl, in particular happy with DBIx::Class and Moose/Moo.

item.title: Smart Shopper = Smart Saver. Perl role in Vienna
item.description: Very well-known Austrian e-commerce brand willing to consider all candidates with strong Perl, but they make heavy use of PostgreSQL, Elasticsearch, and Dancer, any of which would be useful to have experience with.

item.title: Mad Men (and women) of London. Perl in London
item.description: The leader in premium native advertising for technology, financial services, and corporate and lifestyle sectors, our client is the power behind the advertising throne for over 200 websites.This dynamic team is looking for a senior Perl programmer with a strong understanding of Go programming language, paradigms, constructs, and idioms.

item.title: All Aboard to Your Next Adventure! Perl Role in Malta
item.description: Our client has an office in Malta, and they’re looking for you. As a financial company seeing incredible growth over the last two decades, business is booming and they’re looking to expand their team.Looking for Perl developers with a strong background in Modern Perl – you should be comfortable with Moose and PSGI/Plack, and a solid grounding in using Perl’s testing tools.

item.title: The Perl and Raku Conference in the Cloud 2021
item.description: Online 9-11 June 2021.

item.title: Berlin Perl Mongers
item.description: Wednesday, March 31, 2021

item.title: Toronto Perl Mongers Online Meeting
item.description: Thursday, March 25, 2021

item.title: German Perl Workshop 2021
item.description: It will take place online between March 24-26 2021. The private ticket will be cheaper (EUR 30). People who register in time and transfer the participation fee, will get exclusive extras.

item.title: Houston Perl Mongers Online Meeting - Lightning Talks
item.description: March 11th, 2021 06:00 PM Central Time (US and Canada)

item.title: Purdue Perl Mongers - HackLafayette
item.description: Wednesday, March 10, 2021

item.title: Silicon Valley Perl - Regular Expression: Master Manipulator of Text
item.description: Thursday, March 4, 2021

item.title: What to do with legacy Perl code?
What can you do if you become the manager of a Perl development team with a huge legacy code-base?
NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: "Perl in 2025" FOSDEM video review
Perl Review - Perl Weekly Challenge - 099
item.description: Perl Solutions Review by Colin Crain.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 101
item.description: Enjoy quick recap of last week contributions by the Team PWC dealing with the "Pack a Spiral" and "Origin-containing Triangle" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 102
item.description: Welcome new week with couple of fun tasks "Rare Numbers" and "Hash-counting String". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read FAQ page.

item.title: CPAN Mirror List Changes
item.description: From now on the CPAN Mirror list will contain only one entry.

item.title: Browse CPAN modules per namespaces
item.description: There are a few special, or advanced searches in MetaCPAN.They are listed in the FAQ, but that's not easy to notice. Thibault pointed at one of the examples and even suggested a new mode of browsing. What do you think. Would the treeview help you?

item.title: Building a microservice in Perl, part 1: Designing the API
item.description: Creating the OpenAPI design for a simple web application.

item.title: GitHub Actions CI job for Perl Test::Class - checking downstream dependencies as well
item.description: In this video I went over and explained the CI job I set up for Test::Class to try to minimize the risk of changes. It includes running the tests of several downstream distributions and a scheduled job to ensure upstream changes don't break the module during the time no one is working on the code.

item.title: IPC::Cmd considered harmful
item.description: I prefer to use Capture::Tiny, but it is not in the core. (Which is a whole separate discussion.) The post got extensive feedback on Reddit.

item.title: The Hijacking of Perl.com
item.description: The story behind the crime.

item.title: xmpl - visibility API
item.description: So you thought that the neverending series about xmpl was over, didn't you?!? Yet another little facility...

item.title: Way Too Many IF-THEN-ELSEs? Try a Lookup Table
item.description: It is nice to see a (5-dimension) lookup table formatted as, well, a table.

item.title: Line noise
item.description: How to make Perl much more readable by formatting the code. Though I am not sure having a variable called $star = '*'; is a good idea, neither do I easily understand multi-level ternary operators.

item.title: Writing a Perl Core Feature - part 11: Core modules
What return is expected from a function?
item.description: Context in Perl: covering the wantarray, function and the want and howmany functions of Want.pm

item.title: Writing a Perl Core Feature - part 10: Documentation
Exceptional Perl: Failure is an option
item.description: Failure is a universal truth of computers. Files fail to open, web pages fail to load, programs fail to install, messages fail to arrive. As a developer you have no choice but to work in a seemingly hostile environment in which bugs and errors lurk around every corner. - a nice overview of the options in Perl.

item.title: xmpl - remote key/value store healthz revisited
item.description: Changing approach to establish the healthz of a KVStore::Remote object for xmpl. With rationale.

item.title: Random integer generation in an interval with Modern OOP Perl
Sets in Perl using Set::Scalar
item.description: Do you remember sets and Venn diagrams from school? Have you ever needed set operations while programming? It is rarely needed, but when it is then it is good to know you can use a module in Perl to help you.

item.title: Mojo::UserAgent introductory notes
item.description: Some notes about using Mojo as a web client.

item.title: Thoughts, quotes and thoughts about regex
item.description: Regex are one of the superpowers 💪 of Perl

item.title: Writing a Perl Core Feature - part 9: Tests
item.description: Adding a feature or making any changes to code isn't ready till you also wrote tests that verify the new feature and ensure that future changes will not break this feature.

item.title: rt.cpan.org has a new home
item.description: I personally got along with RT, but I think it is great that rt.cpan.org continues living. As a side-efferct it was also upgraded from v4.0.18 to v5.0.

item.title: Multi-OS Universal Perl Package Management
item.description: Use the same tooling across platforms to manage all your Perl environments. Add, remove, update individual dependencies, or install a bundle of curated packages by use-case (eg., a testing tools bundle), to get developing quickly. Learn more & try our new experimental Perl release here!

item.title: #501 - Perl and Quality
item.description:
Hi there!

Recently I wrote quite a few posts about dealing with legacy Perl code in corporations. One of the key things is the need to write automated tests and to set up a CI system. The Perl community was really good at writing tests for the CPAN modules and making it easy to write test. The Perl community (or members of it) even created the CPAN Testers a sort of slow CI system that was one of the best such systems in the early 2000s.

However when I look at the stats I've been collecting it seems that only 50% of recently uploaded CPAN modules have any form of CI system configured. (Actually maybe I should look at the cup half full and celebrate that 50% already have CI? I don't have numbers about other programming language communities.) I keep hoping that more people will embrace the idea. I even recorded a video explaining the new CI system I set up for Test::Class.

rt.cpan.org moved to its new host without any noticable downtime.

MetaCPAN keyboard shortcuts: Did you know that pressing '?' while on MetaCPAN will show you the keyboard shortcuts? I did not. I ran a poll in the Perl programmers group on Facebook: 102 did not know, and only 2 new. One of them being Olaf Alders, who runs MetaCPAN. I also asked on the Perl Maven LinkedIn page. You can still vote there.

Enjoy your week!
